title: Building Number Sense Before (and During) Soroban Training
description: The foundational math understanding that makes soroban learning faster and more effective.
imageAlt: Child developing number sense with manipulatives

content.intro: Soroban is powerful, but it works best when children already have basic number sense. Here's what to build and how.

sections.text: What is Number Sense?
Number sense is intuitive understanding of numbers – what they mean, how they relate, how they behave. It's the difference between knowing "5" as a symbol versus understanding "fiveness."
Key Components for Soroban Readiness
1. One-to-One Correspondence
Understanding that each object gets one count. Pointing to items and counting: 1, 2, 3... without skipping or double-counting.
2. Cardinality
The last number you say IS how many there are. If you count "1, 2, 3, 4" the answer to "how many?" is 4, not start counting again.
3. Conservation
5 blocks spread out = same as 5 blocks grouped tightly. The number doesn't change with arrangement. Young kids don't naturally understand this.
4. Subitizing
Instantly recognizing small quantities without counting. Seeing ●●● and knowing "3" immediately. This is crucial for soroban – recognizing bead patterns at a glance.
Dice, dominoes, and ten-frame activities build subitizing. 5-10 minutes daily of pattern recognition games makes a huge difference.
5. Quantity Comparison
Which is more: 4 or 7? Understanding greater than, less than, equal to. This helps with soroban place value concepts.
6. Composition/Decomposition
5 can be 4+1, 3+2, 2+2+1. Numbers can be broken apart and recombined. This directly maps to soroban complement rules.
Activities to Build Number Sense

rows: Touch and count, set the table (1 fork per person)
Dice games, dot cards, domino matching
"Who has more?" games, sorting by quantity
How many ways to make 5? Use fingers, blocks, snacks

sections.text: When to Start Soroban
A child is ready for soroban when they can:

items: Focus for 5+ minutes on one activity

sections.text: This is typically around age 4-5, though it varies significantly.
Building Number Sense During Soroban
Soroban itself builds number sense when taught well:

items: Place value columns build magnitude understanding
Physical manipulation connects abstract numbers to concrete objects

faq.question: Can soroban help a child who lacks number sense?
faq.answer: Sometimes yes! The visual/tactile nature can help concepts "click" that didn't click through abstract teaching. But very weak number sense may need direct intervention first.

faq.question: What if my 6-year-old still struggles with basic counting?
faq.answer: Focus on number sense activities before soroban. There's no rush. Solid foundations make everything easier later.

faq.question: My child can count to 100 but doesn't seem to understand numbers. Why?
faq.answer: Rote counting ≠ number sense. They've memorized the sequence like a song. Work on subitizing, comparison, and composition separately.

cta.text: SoroKid's beginner levels build number sense alongside soroban skills.
